A Layered Grammar of Graphics: Methods in ggplot2

Published

April 18, 2025

Modified

May 2, 2025

On this page

  • Getting Started
    • Installing R Packages
    • Importing Data
  • What is ggplot2?
  • Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2
    • Data
    • Aesthetic mappings
    • Geom
  • Plotting a Bar Chart
  • Plotting a Dot Plot
  • Plotting a Histogram
  • Plotting a Jitter Plot
  • Plotting a Scatter Plot Smoothing
  • Plotting a Box Plot
  • Combining geom objects

Getting Started

Installing R Packages

The code below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

Code 
pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

Importing Data

Code 
exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
show_col_types = FALSE

knitr::kable(head(exam_data))
ID CLASS GENDER RACE ENGLISH MATHS SCIENCE
Student321 3I Male Malay 21 9 15
Student305 3I Female Malay 24 22 16
Student289 3H Male Chinese 26 16 16
Student227 3F Male Chinese 27 77 31
Student318 3I Male Malay 27 11 25
Student306 3I Female Malay 31 16 16

What is ggplot2?

Applied to visualizations, grammar of graphics is a grammar used to describe and create a wide range of statistical graphics. This layered approach is implemented in ggplot2, an R package for creating data-driven graphics. It has become the go-to tool for making plots flexibly in R.

  • Data: The dataset being plotted.

  • Aesthetics take attributes of the data and use them to influence visual characteristics, such as position, colours, size, shape, or transparency.

  • Geometrics: The visual elements used for our data, such as point, bar or line.

  • Facets split the data into subsets to create multiple variations of the same graph (paneling, multiple plots).

  • Statistics, statiscal transformations that summarise data (e.g. mean, confidence intervals).

  • Coordinate systems define the plane on which data are mapped on the graphic.

  • Themes modify all non-data components of a plot, such as main title, sub-title, y-aixs title, or legend background.

Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2

Let’s examine the first three essential layers for making a plot - Data, Aesthetics and Geometries.

Data

First, let’s call the ggplot() function using the below code.

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data)

Aesthetic mappings

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))

Geom

Geometric objects are the actual marks we put on a plot. A plot must have at least one geom and there is no upper limit. You can add a geom to a plot using the + operator.

Examples include:

  • geom_point() for drawing individual points (e.g., a scatter plot)

  • geom_line() for drawing lines (e.g., for a line charts)

  • geom_bar() for drawing bars (e.g., for bar charts)

  • geom_jitter() to add a small amount of random variation to the location of each point

  • geom_map() for drawing polygons in the shape of a map!

Plotting a Bar Chart

Code 
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) + 
  geom_bar()

Plotting a Dot Plot

Code 
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE,
           y = SCIENCE)) + 
  geom_point()

Plotting a Histogram

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="#630e27")

Plotting a Jitter Plot

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= GENDER, 
           y= SCIENCE)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.5, height = 0.5,
              bins=20, 
              aes(colour = "#630e27"))

Plotting a Scatter Plot Smoothing

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(linewidth=0.5)

Plotting a Box Plot

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()

Combining geom objects

Code 
ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(y=MATHS,
           x=GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(position="jitter",
             size=0.5)

# Getting Started

## Installing R Packages

The code below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

```{r}
pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

```

## Importing Data

```{r}
exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
show_col_types = FALSE

knitr::kable(head(exam_data))
```

# What is ggplot2?

Applied to visualizations, **grammar of graphics** is a grammar used to describe and create a wide range of statistical graphics. This layered approach is implemented in **ggplot2**, an R package for creating data-driven graphics. It has become the go-to tool for making plots flexibly in R.

![](images/clipboard-950964217.png){fig-align="center" width="472"}

-   **Data**: The dataset being plotted.

-   **Aesthetics** take attributes of the data and use them to influence visual characteristics, such as position, colours, size, shape, or transparency.

-   **Geometrics**: The visual elements used for our data, such as point, bar or line.

-   **Facets** split the data into subsets to create multiple variations of the same graph (paneling, multiple plots).

-   **Statistics**, statiscal transformations that summarise data (e.g. mean, confidence intervals).

-   **Coordinate systems** define the plane on which data are mapped on the graphic.

-   **Themes** modify all non-data components of a plot, such as main title, sub-title, y-aixs title, or legend background.

# **Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2**

Let's examine the first three essential layers for making a plot - Data, Aesthetics and Geometries.

## **Data**

First, let's call the ggplot() function using the below code.

```{r}
#| eval: false
ggplot(data=exam_data)
```

## Aesthetic mappings

```{r}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))
```

## Geom

Geometric objects are the actual marks we put on a plot. A plot must have at least one geom and there is no upper limit. You can add a geom to a plot using the **+** operator.

Examples include:

-   ***geom_point()*** for drawing individual points (e.g., a scatter plot)

-   ***geom_line()*** for drawing lines (e.g., for a line charts)

-   ***geom_bar()*** for drawing bars (e.g., for bar charts)

-   ***geom_jitter()*** to add a small amount of random variation to the location of each point

-   ***geom_map()*** for drawing polygons in the shape of a map!

# Plotting a Bar Chart

```{r}
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) + 
  geom_bar()

```

# Plotting a Dot Plot

```{r}
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE,
           y = SCIENCE)) + 
  geom_point()
```

# Plotting a Histogram

```{r}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="#630e27") 

```

# Plotting a Jitter Plot

```{r}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= GENDER, 
           y= SCIENCE)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.5, height = 0.5,
              bins=20, 
              aes(colour = "#630e27"))
```

# Plotting a Scatter Plot Smoothing

```{r}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(linewidth=0.5)
```

# Plotting a Box Plot

```{r}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

# **Combining *geom* objects**

```{r}
ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(y=MATHS,
           x=GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(position="jitter",
             size=0.5)
```
